newsitem.title: USA: Microsoft plans to extend "push" format.
newsitem.headline: Microsoft plans to extend "push" format.

text.p: In a move designed to simplify Internet standards, Microsoft Corp said Thursday it will make its "push" technology compatible with software from rival Netscape Communications Corp.

Microsoft said the change in its channel definition format will allow publishers to write content in a single format that will work both with its forthcoming Internet Explorer version 4.0 and with Netscape's Netcaster client software, due out in about a month.
"Now Microsoft and Netscape don't have to compete on the channel format standard but more importantly can focus on implementation," a Microsoft spokeswoman said.
The Microsoft format is intended to make it easier for developers to prepare content that can be sent directly to predefined "channels" on its Internet browser.
Netscape has eschewed the new format, saying developers can achieve the same effect using existing Internet formats and scripting languages.

While Microsoft has been gaining share in the browser market, most Internet users still use Netscape's Navigator browser, so it was in Microsoft's interest to provide developers a single standard that works on both browsers, said Dwight Davis, editor of Windows Watcher, an industry newsletter.
